newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Hungary marks '56 uprising amid political rancour.
newsitem.headline: Hungary marks '56 uprising amid political rancour.

text.p: Hungary began marking the 40th anniversary of the 1956 anti-Soviet uprising on Tuesday in ceremonies pointedly shunning the former communists who now run the country.

"It was the revolution of human dignity," Hungarian President Arpad Goncz said during an awards ceremony for those who fought in the uprising, which posed the biggest challenge at that time to Soviet domination of eastern Europe.

"I am happy, but there is also a touch of sadness in these celebrations," said Maria Wittner, who as a young woman joined demonstrations in 1956 and made petrol bombs to throw at Soviet tanks. She was sentenced to death but later released.

"Quite a number of our comrades who are gone have still not been rehabilitated or received the recognition they deserve," Wittner told Reuters after the crowded ceremony for about 400 people at the Budapest General Assembly.

The first shots of the uprising were fired on October 23, 1956 as Hungarians fought in the streets with small arms and petrol bombs against Soviet tanks and troops. A Soviet invasion in November crushed the revolution, in which an estimated 25,000 people were killed.
On Tuesday, Hungarians commemorated the events leading up to the fighting, with most ceremonies pointedly organised by associations of 1956 veterans and not by the government.

"The current government is really not suitable to celebrate the 40th anniversary," Karoly Herenyi, spokesman for the conservative opposition Hungarian Democratic Forum party, said of the Hungarian Socialist Party, which took power in 1994 and is comprised largely of former communists.

"This government is really not able to do a proper job," Herenyi said during a reception at the MDF's headquarters on Monday evening which brought together several ageing veterans and leaders of the uprising.

"What we want to get across is the happiness of the victory of 40 years ago but we also must remember the treason (the communists) committed, as a consequence of which Hungary remained a Soviet colony for another 30-odd years," said Jeno Fonay, who was in prison for more than six years and heads an organisation of former political prisoners.

Fonay said that if Socialist Prime Minister Gyula Horn attended a reception at Parliament on Wednesday night, people would be watching to see who shook hands with him and Horn would be lucky if no one poured champagne on him.
"The problem is that the communists are still here," Fonay told Reuters. "They are just in sheepskins."
Horn served in a militia organised after the uprising to put down continuing anti-Soviet strikes and protests, but he has said he never used a gun.

President Goncz, who was sentenced to life imprisonment after the uprising, acknowledged in a television interview on Monday the rancour attending the anniversary and suggested it would be best if the government took a "hands off" approach.
"We have to ignore the unnecessary legends of the 1956 revolutions and the celebrations have to be brought closer to the people," Goncz said.
"We must end the official character of it and accept the idea that it is first of all the holiday of those who participated in it."
